New Records: Yoshinobu Yamamoto allowed two hits over five innings for the win, joining Orel Hershiser, Jerry Reuss, Sandy Koufax, and Johnny Podres as the only Dodgers pitchers with a scoreless start of at least five innings in a winner-take-all postseason game.
Key Match Events: Yoshinobu Yamamoto outdueled Yu Darvish in a historic postseason matchup of Japanese-born starters, and the Dodgers got home runs from Kiké Hernández and Teoscar Hernández to beat the San Diego Padres 2-0 on Friday and advance to the National League Championship Series.
The teams combined to retire 26 consecutive batters — the longest streak in a single game in postseason history.
Pre-Game Insights: Analysts predicted a close game between the two rival teams.
The manager emphasized the importance of strong bullpen performance.
Post-Match Reflections: Mookie Betts said, 'We're the ones popping bottles now.'
Padres manager Mike Shildt said, 'I think stunning is appropriate.'
Manny Machado added, 'It’s a devastating one for sure.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Dodgers won a decisive Game 5 at home for the first time since taking a 1981 NL Division Series against Houston after a season split into halves following a players' strike.
The 38-year-old Darvish, who was Ohtani's childhood idol, gave up an early home run to Kiké Hernández, then set down 14 in a row.
Others: The wild-card Padres ended the series scoreless since the second inning of Game 3.
Los Angeles led 1-0 on the drive by Kiké Hernández with two outs in the second.
The Dodgers staved off elimination in San Diego with an 8-0 victory in Game 4 to force the deciding game back home.
